headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be the conference operator for today's call. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fortune Brands' First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the c
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be the conference operator for today's call. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fortune Brands' First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Carbonari, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Fortune Brands. You may begin, sir.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christie. Good morning. Welcome to our discussion of Fortune Brands' first quarter results. Please note that our presentation includes forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, including those listed in t
componenttext:
Thanks, Christie. Good morning. Welcome to our discussion of Fortune Brands' first quarter results. Please note that our presentation includes forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, including those listed in the cautionary language at the end of our news release. The actual results could differ materially from those targeted. 
The terms of this presentation also include certain non-GAAP measures that are reconciled to the most closely comparable GAAP measures in our news release or on our website in the Supplemental Information link to the Webcast pages.
With strong double-digit growth in sales, operating income and earnings per share, Fortune Brands is off to an excellent start in 2010. Our strong first quarter results were driven by the powerful combination of higher volumes and lower costs, as each of our three brand groups outperformed our expectations.
Our sales reflected strong sales gains for our Spirits and Home Products brands. These results reflect market share gains, improved consumer markets, rebuilding of inventory by channel partners in certain Home Products categories, foreign exchange and favorable year-over-year comparisons.
Over the course of the downturn, we focused sharply in positioning Fortune Brands for strong growth when the economy recovers. And those initiatives are clearly paying off. Our innovations and strategic brand investments are helping fuel top line growth. And we're driving even stronger growth at the bottom line as we leverage our lower cost structures. We're also pleased that the momentum we saw in the fourth quarter continued to build as we began 2010.
In the marketplace, we've seen consumers getting more active, which reinforces our confidence that this is an excellent time to invest in brand growth and go on offense. Our strategic investments in Spirits help drive growth for our brand portfolio in all global regions, including share gains in key markets for brands such as Jim Beam, Maker's Mark and Sauza. In Home Products, better-than-expected remodeling activity, shared gains at home centers, rebuilding of inventory by customers in faucets and doors and favorable comparisons helped drive double-digit sales gains for our cabinetry brands as well as Moen kitchen and bath products, ThermaTru doors and Simonton windows. In Golf, successful new products helped drive higher sales for Titleist golf clubs and FootJoy shoes. 
Now let's take a closer look at the numbers for the first quarter. Net income was $72 million or $0.47 per diluted share. We recorded charges in the quarter amounting to $0.02 cents per share. Craig will touch on these a little later. Excluding charges and gains, diluted earnings per share was $0.49. That's up 63% from $0.30 in the year-ago period.
Net sales were $1.63 billion; that's up 13%. On a comparable basis, sales from the quarter were up 7%, but the comparable measures exclude excise tax, foreign exchange, acquisition and divestitures, and the impact of required accounting for our new international Spirits distribution structure, comparable net sales were up 7% in Spirits, up 13% in Home and Security and off 3% in Golf. Reported operating income came in at $156 million. On the before-charges-and-gain basis, operating income was $161 million for the quarter. That's up 33%, largely reflecting strong year-over-year growth and operating income in Home and Security.
Reviewing our assets and investment return measures, after-tax return on net tangible assets before charges and gains was 15%. Working capital efficiency came in at 37%. Asset-maturing inventories for Spirits WC [working capital] was 20%. Return on equity before charges and gains was 8%. And return on invested capital before charges and gains was 6%.
I mentioned earlier we're benefiting from the work we've done over the course of the downturn. Let me discuss what I mean. First, during the downturn, we continued to make sensible investments, and our trusted brands keep consumers excited. These investments include brand-friendly programs, sustaining new product innovation and expanded offering across price points. We also continue to support expansion to adjacent product categories in promising international markets.
To underscore the success of these initiatives, in 2009, 25% of our sales came from products introduced in just the past three years. The percentage of our sales for markets outside the U.S. continues to grow, reaching 33% in the first quarter. And in the first quarter 2010, we continue to outperform our markets in Home and Golf. And we began to see the benefits of our strategy investments in our Spirits business.
Combined with our aggressive initiative to reduce cost structures, enhance supply chain flexibility and manage our cash, these initiatives helped Fortune Brands emerge from the recession in a strong position. And it positions us well to drive strong growth as the economy comes back.  As we said before, we believe the front end of a recovery is a great time to invest to gain competitive advantage, and that's our approach here in 2010. We're planning higher strategic investment in brand building programs, new product innovation and international expansion initiatives in promising markets.
Given the signs of increased consumer activity as well as greater confidence in returning to EPS growth in 2010, we are further boosting our strategic investments as we previously indicated we would. When it comes to our Spirits business, we're increasing strategic brand investments by double digits in 2010. And that began in the first quarter. We are deploying these investments primarily behind our core categories, our biggest brands, new products and our biggest market opportunities. As part of that, we're reaching consumers in new ways. In fact, 35% of our media spend this year in Spirits will be for digital media, up from less than 20% in 2009. That includes our new multimedia partnership with our flagship Jim Beam brand and ESPN. This creative program is led by, "The next round -- served up Jim Beam," a first-of-its kind web series that premiered earlier this month on ESPN.com, SportsCenter and ESPN Radio.
It also includes an innovative partnership program launched yesterday with Kid Rock and Atlantic Records, featuring exclusive digital downloads of Kid Rock music on limited-edition bottles of Jim Beam and Red Stag. Jim Beam is the first spirits brand to partner with a major record label in this kind of music distribution program. 
And there's a lot more. This week, we launched the first ever key advertising in the U.S. for Hornitos tequila. We also recently launched new brand-building programs behind brands such as EFFEN vodka, Cruzan rum and Canadian Club RTDs [ready-to-drink] in Australia.
Our innovations in Spirits are focused around four areas: flavor, convenience, premiumization and value. And here are some of our innovations: First, Red Stag by Jim Beam, which tripled our expectations in 2009 continues to grow in [Audio Gap]. Second, we relaunched double-aged Jim Beam Black with great new packaging. This is followed up by the soon-to-be-launched Maker's 46, a much-anticipated new expression from Maker's Mark. At the value end, we just launched Old Crow Reserve bourbon. 
And to continue to adjust to the at-home consumption trend, we've expanded our successful Cocktail Cube line to include Cruzan Mojitos and Sauza Strawberry Margaritas. And finally, we're bringing innovation to international markets as well, with new RTD [ready-to-drink] products in Australia and Teacher's Origin in India. We have a great lineup of innovations in 2010.
To build positions in key markets, we're leveraging our new sales and distribution organization that we've built over the past two years. Let me highlight that the increased costs for our international marketing initiatives annualized at the end of the first quarter. Furthermore, we believe we're elevating our performance, enhancing our prospects with a more efficient and effective organization. That includes a winding of our U.S. sales organization by distributor rather than region; implementation of six focused units, three in the U.S. and three international; and enhancement of our team with the best talent from both inside and outside the industry. In addition, cost savings and operating efficiencies are helping fuel our growth initiatives in Spirits. 
In Home and Security products, I'm pleased to say that we haven't spent through the housing recession hunker down. We've been prudent in navigating the downturn and aggressively positioning ourselves for competitive advantage when conditions improve. We began to see the results of this approach in the fourth quarter of '09, and our initiatives delivered again in the first quarter of 2010. As we've discussed before, we've been very proactive in taking costs out our Home and Security business. By reducing the number of facilities and head counts by 40% during the downturn and pursuing continuous improvement, today we have a lean cost structure, but also very flexible supply chain. These moves are clearly paying off in positive operating leverage as volume returns. And underscoring our supply chain flexibility, we were pleased last week to announce the addition of more than 300 jobs over the next three years in our cabinetry plant in North Carolina due to an upcoming piece of new business.
On the growth side, we're essentially investing in profitable share gain initiatives, new product innovations and expansion into adjacent and international markets. We're also leveraging our broad product offerings, industry-leading lead times and after-sales service to expand relationships with key customers and gain profitable market share. 
Moen, our largest single brand, continues to roll out new products and designs with advanced functionality, innovation and eco-performance benefits. New products are helping Moen gain shelf space at home centers. And the brand also returned to television advertising in the quarter to reinforce its position as the number one faucet brand in North America. Internationally, Moen continues to expand in China and lay the foundation for growth in India. Last year alone, Moen opened and renovated more than 165 showrooms in China and opened its first 40 showrooms in India, where it also established a new assembly facility.
Our cabinetry brands are gaining substantial market share at home centers, where consumers are increasingly making cabinetry purchases. We're expanding with these customers by offering new product lines to fill price gaps, value-added design features and added tools to help kitchen designers sell our brands. Meanwhile, we're staying aggressive in the dealer channel, where we historically have been very strong.
Simonton and ThermaTru are leveraging advanced materials and state-of-the-art features to deliver products that combine aesthetic beauty with energy efficiency. Simonton, in particular, has generated strong growth and new jobs on the back of the U.S. tax credit for consumers' purchases of efficiency home products.
Master Lock continues to deliver evolutionary and revolutionary new products, while expanding effectively in adjacent security categories such as electronic security in international markets like Europe, Canada and Latin America.
In Golf, we have the game's most trusted brands, and we remain focused on outperforming the market through innovation and international expansion. We continue to excel at the high end of the market, with the success of the industry-leading Titleist Pro V1 golf ball and advanced performance Titleist golf clubs. In clubs, demand for the next generation Titleist AP1 and AP2 irons continues to grow. Our Vokey design wedges has gained significant year-over-year market share. And with new advanced performance models like the new California series, Scotty Cameron by Titleist putters is growing share. 
In the quarter, we also launched a new Titleist driver in Japan designed specifically for the Japanese market, which is off to a very strong start. On the PGA Tour so far this year, Titleist has been the most played in balls, irons, wedges and putter categories and the number two brand in drivers. Our Golf innovations extend across price points. And we've introduced the next-generation Titleist NXT, NXT Tour golf balls as well as the new Titleist DT SoLo. In shoes, the new flagship FootJoy ICON is off to an excellent start. And the new FootJoy Sport is bringing excitement to the category.
The Golf industry's best growth opportunities are in international markets. And we've been investing successfully to capitalize in these markets. These investments include developing industry-leading sales organizations in key markets across the Pacific Rim and the construction of a new golf plant to serve these markets. This new plant will begin production here in the second quarter. Our investments have helped drive our percentage of golf sales from international markets to 47%. 
One final note in Golf, earlier this month, we completed the sale of Cobra golf brand to Puma. Divesting the Cobra brand enables us to concentrate our golf investments entirely behind our industry-leading Titleist and FootJoy brands. These are trusted brands with heritages of powerful innovation and strong brand equity. We believe Titleist and FootJoy represent our highest return growth opportunities in golf. To further underscore the strength of the Titleist brand in 2009, Titleist golf clubs' sales grew in a golf market that declined at a mid-teen rate.
We used the proceeds to pay down debt, which remained a priority for us. Naturally, it enhances our financial flexibility. Now, here's Craig with a closer look at our market and the first quarter performance for each of our segments.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bruce. We'll start with Spirits. We entered 2010 with an expectation that the global spirits markets would be relatively stable, with overall growth in the range of flat to up 1%. We're happy to say we're encouraged by what we saw across our marke
componenttext:
Thanks, Bruce. We'll start with Spirits. We entered 2010 with an expectation that the global spirits markets would be relatively stable, with overall growth in the range of flat to up 1%. We're happy to say we're encouraged by what we saw across our markets in the first quarter. Here in the U.S., we're seeing stabilization on premise and favorable consumption trends. We're also seeing encouraging signs in select international markets, including Australia, our second-largest Spirits market. 
Now, let's look at our numbers for the quarter. Spirit sales for the quarter came in at $573 million, up 18%. Sales were up 7% on a comparable basis. And that excludes the impact of foreign exchange, excise taxes, acquisition/divestitures and the impact of required accounting for our new international distribution alliance. Case volume shipments increased slightly faster than revenues. 
Also of note, various one-off benefits including favorable comparison in markets such as Mexico, the U.K. and duty-free. And the timing of bulk sales accounted for about half of that 7%. Geographically, comparable net sales for our brands were up 2% in the U.S. and up 15% internationally. Outside the U.S., we benefited from strong sales gains in Australia and double-digit increases in markets including the U.K., Canada, Mexico and the collective BRIC markets. 
At the operating income line, OI before charges came in at $119 million, down 9%. Lower year-over-year OI margin was a function of several factors. The impact of the significant double-digit increase in strategic brand investments that we discussed three months ago, our previously announced incremental Route-to-market costs that annualized during the quarter, along with related international duties that we now record in sales and adverse foreign exchange as well as some degree of price mix.
As a reminder here, we held back on brand spend in the first half of 2009. So our stepped-up investment was magnified here in the first quarter. It will also impact Q2. Looking at the year-to-date performance of our key brands, net sales in constant currency and excluding excise taxes were higher for each of our three Spirits' consumer categories. That's up mid-single-digit rate for our industry-leading Bourbon portfolio; up mid-single digits for mixables, which includes tequila, rum, vodka, gin and cordial; and up double digits for classics, which is our cognac, Canadian and Scotch Whiskey. 
In Bourbon, our flagship Jim Beam brand grew worldwide sales on strong performance in the U.S., including the success of Red Stag and Jim Beam Rye. Maker's Mark continued to make strong gains in international markets including Australia, the brand's largest export market. And Knob Creek posted double-digit gains against the year-ago quarter when supply was running short. 
In our Mixable category, Sauza tequila sales were up at a double-digit rate on a big bounce back in Mexico against an easy comparison, plus growth for Sauza Gold and Blanco in the U.S.
For our cordial brands, sales of DeKuyper were up modestly in the U.S., while Sourz grew at a double-digit rate in Europe. And Cruzan rum gained share in the U.S. 
In the Classics category, sales for Courvoisier were up at a strong double-digit rate on strong growth in Europe, Asia and global duty-free. Canadian Club sales were up slightly. Laphroaig Scotch grew sales at a double-digit rate. And Teacher's was higher on strong sales in India and Brazil.
Looking to the rest of the year in Spirits. It now appears the global spirits market in 2010 may be up a point or so better than our earlier expectations of flat to up a percent. As we've already shared with you, we believe investing in our brands in 2010 is an excellent opportunity to help drive sustainable, profitable, long-term growth. And the progress we're making and encouraging market dynamics have reinforced that decision.
Our current outlook is that brand and strategic investments will pick up at a mid-teens rate year-over-year versus the approximately 10% estimate we talked about in January. The incremental spend will go against our digital media efforts, recent innovations that have momentum and our smaller brands with significant growth potential. That increased level of investment, coupled with our current outlook, will likely result in margins for 2010 in the range of 23%. I would highlight that, that continues to be among the best in the industry, that we're already getting traction in the marketplace from our initiatives investments, and that we are expecting further returns going forward.
Turning to Home and Security. We entered the year with an assumption that the overall home products market would be flat to up modestly. Included in that estimate was an assumption that spending on replace/remodel would be down in the low to mid-single-digit range, but spending on new construction would be up about 20% and that spending in the cabinets' market, as a big-ticket discretionary purchase, would lag the market and be down at a low to mid-single-digit rate.
Although the home products market still faces headwinds, we are seeing continued signs of stabilization. Spending on replace/remodel, new construction and cabinetry were all better than we expected in the first quarter. As a result, our current target is based on an assumption that the overall home product market will be up low-single digits in 2010, better than we anticipated three months ago. That estimate assumes new construction spending will be up in the range of 15% to 20%, overall replace/remodel spending flat to up to low-single digits and that spending for cabinetry will be off low-single digits.
Turning to the numbers. First quarter sales came in at $698 million, up 15%, reflecting double-digit increases for cabinetry, faucets, windows and doors. The top line benefited from broad-based share gains, inventory rebuilding by channel partners in faucets and doors and favorable comparison to the results of the year-ago quarter. Operating income before charges grew from negative $23 million a year ago to positive $24 million in the current quarter. That's the second consecutive quarterly increase in Home and Security.
Our strong OI growth in Home and Security reflects favorable operating leverage that resulted from higher volumes on top of our significantly lower cost structures. While we're obviously pleased that OI leveraged at 50% in the first quarter, that rate reflects cost benefits that are annualizing as the year progresses and flat year-over-year raw material costs. As we highlighted in the press release, raw materials will be a headwind in the coming quarters.
Bottom line, the underlying run rate was in the range of 30%, in line with our full-year expectations. Drilling down, sales from Moen increased more than 20% on strong gains for new products at home centers, inventory rebuilding in the wholesale channel and very strong growth in China and Canada.
Sales for our cabinetry brands were up at a high-teens rate, driven by very strong growth from share gains for our differentiated offerings at home centers, strong gains with builders and dealers and the benefit of favorable comparison.
Sales of windows and doors also increased in the high teens. Simonton windows continue to benefit from share gains and the federal tax credit for energy-efficient home purchases. Results for ThermaTru doors benefited from favorable product mix, as demand grew for higher-end fiberglass entry doors.
Sales on security and storage products were slightly higher, as growth for Master Lock more than offset lower sales for Waterloo organization products. 
As we look to the balance of the year in Home and Security, despite the stabilization we've seen, the Home Products market still faces headwinds. While big-ticket remodeling has improved somewhat, we still expect consumers to remain cautious. The new homes being built are generally smaller, entry-level homes with fewer faucets and windows. And it remains to be seen how foreclosures, as well as the expiration of the homebuyer tax credit here in the second quarter, will impact the market.
That said, we were able to outperform the market and gain share in the first quarter. And we feel well-positioned to continue outperforming. Our cost and productivity initiatives are helping us at the bottom line, even as we boost strategic investments and face increased cost for commodities such as copper, zinc, steel and transportation. Of note since our January call, each of these commodities is up double digits. All in, we now anticipate full year OI margins will be up a point or so versus our prior estimate of flat to up modestly.
Moving on to Golf. We expect the industry to return to growth in 2010, after a double-digit decline in spending on golf in 2009. Despite soft first quarter industry conditions, partly due to lower rounds of play caused by adverse weather in U.S. warm weather locations, we're seeing golf consumers responding favorably to new product innovations in advance of the prime playing months as well as growth in the international market. 
We continue to expect that worldwide spending on golf equipment will be up at a low single-digit rate for the year. Our first quarter golf sales were $354 million, that's up 2%. On a constant-currency basis, sales were up 3% from the year-ago quarter, which benefited from the launch of the new Pro V1. Geographically, sales were lower in the U.S. In international markets, sales in constant currency were lower in Europe and Japan, but up strongly in Korea, the PAC Basin and Latin America. Operating income in golf was $44 million, up 27% before charges, reflecting the benefit of foreign exchange and successful productivity initiatives.
On a product-line basis, sales of golf balls were modestly lower due to challenging comparisons to the launch of new Pro V1 models in the year-ago quarter; as well as, again, the impact of poor weather on rounds of play. Worth noting is that while the early months of the year are relatively small, rounds of play in the U.S. were down more than 20% year-to-date through February due to the unusually bad weather.
Sales of Titleist golf clubs were up at a mid-single-digit rate, reflecting small demand for new Titleist iron models, as well as Scotty Cameron putters and the introduction in March of a driver designed specifically for the Japanese market.
Sales of FootJoy shoes rose at a double-digit rate on shipments of new ICON, Sport and eComfort models. FootJoy has gained significant share in the U.S. on- and off-course shoe market year-over-year, and those gains accelerated in the first quarter. The success of ICON and Sport is helping drive favorable mix shift.
Sale of gloves and accessories also increased at a double-digit rate. Looking to 2010, we are very well-positioned to reinforce our industry leadership. With a sharp focus on outperforming the industry, we'll continue to invest in our trusted brands, new product innovations and growth initiatives in attractive international market.
Now before turning things back to Bruce, just a few additional items. Reviewing charges for the quarter, we recorded after-tax restructuring-related charges of $3 million, or $0.02 per share. That's related to previously announced projects in both Spirits and Home. 
With regard to our tax rate, our rate came in at 28.3% for the quarter, but approximately two points were attributable to the true-up of deferred taxes related to the recently enacted healthcare bill. We continue to target that our full-year rate will be in the 26% to 27% range.
Turning to cash flow. Our target for 2010 remains $375 million to $475 million. And as a reminder, that's cash flow from operations less net capital expenditures. It also excludes the proceeds from the sale of the Cobra golf assets. That target represents an earnings to free cash flow conversion rate of more than 100%. We're particularly pleased about that.
Now back to Bruce for some final comments on our 2010 outlook.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Craig. Our goal entering the year was for Fortune Brands to return to EPS growth in 2010. And our first quarter results enhance our confidence in achieving that goal. Earlier this week as a result of our strong first quarter, we raised the bottom
componenttext:
Thanks, Craig. Our goal entering the year was for Fortune Brands to return to EPS growth in 2010. And our first quarter results enhance our confidence in achieving that goal. Earlier this week as a result of our strong first quarter, we raised the bottom end of our earnings target range. We now are targeting to deliver EPS before charges and gains for 2010 in the range of $2.50 to $2.80. That's versus our prior target of $2.30 to $2.80.
As we indicated on Tuesday, we're holding the high end of our range, because there is still uncertainty in global economies, and it remains to be seen how the expiration of the U.S. government's stimulus program will impact home products demand. In addition, raw material costs have increased. The U.S. dollar has strengthened, and as previously indicated, we are increasing high-return strategic investments in our brands to capitalize on the improved consumer environment.
All that said, we feel very well-positioned to deliver improved results. We expect the markets for each of our brand groups will be up at a low single-digit rate for the year. And we're aiming to outperform our categories, by continuing to invest in our brands and leverage our lower cost structures. Thank you, again, for joining us. 
Now Craig and I will be happy to take any questions.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question on your Home segment, if I could. First growth we've seen out of top line in three years. Yet, there was some inventory build and cabinets were performing quite nicely. But your guidance is still for a low single-digit decline at least m
componenttext: I have a question on your Home segment, if I could. First growth we've seen out of top line in three years. Yet, there was some inventory build and cabinets were performing quite nicely. But your guidance is still for a low single-digit decline at least market-wise for the year. Can you just help us understand how much the inventory build or other factors might have helped your quarter? And where would the weakness might come in cabinets in the balance of the year relative to your guidance?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly, we saw a great performance in the first quarter as you outlined. As we look at the balance of the year, as we said in our prepared comments, we're just taking a cautious approach at this point. I mean, we think with the new normal and consumer co
componenttext: Clearly, we saw a great performance in the first quarter as you outlined. As we look at the balance of the year, as we said in our prepared comments, we're just taking a cautious approach at this point. I mean, we think with the new normal and consumer consciousness about big-ticket and where things stand with credit availability, that being cautious at this point is the right thing. Now, obviously to the degree that, that opens up, then those results could be better. But as you talk about the build of inventories out there in the channels with select consumers, obviously, in cabinets we don't have that. What's ordered is built and shipped. And so the results are the results.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Where would the build come from and how much did that help your quarter?
componenttext: Where would the build come from and how much did that help your quarter?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me, Dave, just re-framed this a little bit differently. Our business, the majority of the business is made-to-orders, both windows and cabinets. So when you look at our growth rate, a portion of it was some inventory build in faucets and in doors, but
componenttext: Let me, Dave, just re-framed this a little bit differently. Our business, the majority of the business is made-to-orders, both windows and cabinets. So when you look at our growth rate, a portion of it was some inventory build in faucets and in doors, but the majority was share gain. I would think more -- about half to maybe a little bit more was share gain.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could just follow-up on Spirits, you've indicated some stabilization in the on-premise. Looking to the U.S. where your sales were up 2%, can you look at the on-premise and the take-home and just kind of walk us through the consumer behavior chang
componenttext: And if I could just follow-up on Spirits, you've indicated some stabilization in the on-premise. Looking to the U.S. where your sales were up 2%, can you look at the on-premise and the take-home and just kind of walk us through the consumer behavior changes that you might be seeing?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Interestingly enough, Spirits business in the U.S. has performed well in the first quarter. We saw stabilization in on-premise, meaning that the declines we saw last couple of years have really started to stabilize through the third, fourth quarter now an
componenttext: Interestingly enough, Spirits business in the U.S. has performed well in the first quarter. We saw stabilization in on-premise, meaning that the declines we saw last couple of years have really started to stabilize through the third, fourth quarter now and into the first quarter. We also saw that the price mix was very good. It was stable to improving and the basic volume was up. So our view of the first quarter, when you look at yields and then the controlled states combined, it was up for the last 13 weeks in the 3% range. And if you look at the most current four weeks data, it's even growing faster than that. So a real positive response again to the market, I think. Again, for our particular business, innovations in some of our core brands are really driving our performance.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other noteworthy point here is that we talked about the fact that reported sales are up, the 18% level. But on a true underlying basis, we were more in the 3% percent range. But that was very much in line with the market, but that's encouragin
componenttext: I think the other noteworthy point here is that we talked about the fact that reported sales are up, the 18% level. But on a true underlying basis, we were more in the 3% percent range. But that was very much in line with the market, but that's encouraging at this point.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dennis McGill with Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dennis McGill with Zelman & Associates.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, are you specifically talking about the housing side, Dennis?
componenttext: Sure, are you specifically talking about the housing side, Dennis?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It really is the general economy. And I would say that the housing market is probably the one that we see the raw material and the housing tax credit, actually tomorrow, I guess, going away. So I think the consumer environment generally is one that -- con
componenttext: It really is the general economy. And I would say that the housing market is probably the one that we see the raw material and the housing tax credit, actually tomorrow, I guess, going away. So I think the consumer environment generally is one that -- consumer is back active again. They are still demanding value. And where and how we're positioned with our brands really plays to that. I mean, we have very trusted brands that basically, the price-value equation is very competitive. And we continue to invest behind these brands and the innovation addition behind. So we try to keep the consumers in the market very excited. So when you say that, you guys say, "Okay, what's really going to fuel this thing?" And the answer to that, I think in the U.S. it's going to be jobs, jobs and people feeling more confident about what's in their wallet and go out and spend a little bit more aggressively on their home. There's obviously a pent-up demand, not only in what they want to do in their home, but also  when you just look at the basic math of housing formations versus housing starts over the last couple of years. It's just, I believe, that people have to feel more comfortable with what's going to happen in the general economy. I would also say that we are going in the Home business and the Golf business, we're going into fairly big quarters here. The second quarter is the spring selling season for home. It's also the start of the golf season here. So until we see the second quarter and really see how that plays out, I think that will really fortify more our confidence for the year.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes.
componenttext: Oh, yes.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, it's always -- yes. I think that the raw material piece is a piece that in the first quarter, we really didn't have much impact. It's just building over the year. But end demand right now is probably the one that we would like to see a little bi
componenttext: Yes, yes, it's always -- yes. I think that the raw material piece is a piece that in the first quarter, we really didn't have much impact. It's just building over the year. But end demand right now is probably the one that we would like to see a little bit more solidification. One quarter, two quarters really now for us, have been positive, but we just need to see more.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Dennis, just a point there, commodities were basically flat for us year-over-year in the first quarter. But looking out to the full year and our expectation is that raw material costs along with say ocean freight and transportation, we're looking at
componenttext: And, Dennis, just a point there, commodities were basically flat for us year-over-year in the first quarter. But looking out to the full year and our expectation is that raw material costs along with say ocean freight and transportation, we're looking at something that's going to be in the range of making incrementally say, $50 million or so year-over-year. So that's to come. And when you look at FX, the benefit that we derived in the first quarter really represents, at current exchange rates, about 2/3 of what we were expecting would be the benefit for the full year. So when you look at the numbers for the first quarter, I mean, we're really, really pleased. And I think it evidences that we've done the right thing to position in the marketplace for growth. We've done the right things on the cost structure. But it's also a quarter where the stars really aligned. So back to Bruce's point, when you look at the Spirits market, somewhat better than we expected; Golf, still expecting up kind of low-single digits or so. The real driver here is what's going to happen with the consumer in home, in terms of purchasing new homes and where they stand with repair and remodel.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I would say, Dennis, too, that I really like where our businesses are positioned. We've done all the work. We've leaned out our cost structures. We are basically done with restructure, we were basically done with that the middle of last year. And
componenttext: Yes, and I would say, Dennis, too, that I really like where our businesses are positioned. We've done all the work. We've leaned out our cost structures. We are basically done with restructure, we were basically done with that the middle of last year. And we are in a very flexible supply chain leading position to be able to leverage when the volume continues. I like where our businesses are; it's more about the market.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It is.
componenttext: It is.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that question with what's happening in the marketplace. I think everyone last year in the Spirits industry -- and this is a generalization, obviously -- pulled back on brand expense somewhat, just to see where the consumer is g
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that question with what's happening in the marketplace. I think everyone last year in the Spirits industry -- and this is a generalization, obviously -- pulled back on brand expense somewhat, just to see where the consumer is going to be and what was happening. We might have pulled back a little bit more, mostly because we were going through the international route, the market change in the first half of the year. And as we then started to see the stabilization of the market -- I'm talking about us now -- and to see some of our innovations really start to take hold and some momentum in some particular markets, we decided to fuel those. We want to see, for example, Red Stag, it had a phenomenal start, and can this become a million-case brand. Well, let's go see and let's fund it. So when we have energy behind things, we want to put and continue to put money behind that to see how far we can take that. And I think that's part of what you're seeing here in the Spirits business. We have created some momentums in areas, and we want to see how far we can take that. Regarding the overall margin, again, the 23% is one of the higher ones in the industry. We are spending against brands that we think, both from a market and from a growth and return situation, are good return on investment propositions. That doesn't mean every brand is going to get funded. But the ones that we think have the most potential to grow and the best returns are the ones we're going to hit on harder.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me jump in here too, because we in January told you that we were targeting that margins would be in the range of say, 24%, down 50, 60 bps or so from where we were last year. Obviously, the move to 23%, the 1% or so is a function of the higher brand s
componenttext: Let me jump in here too, because we in January told you that we were targeting that margins would be in the range of say, 24%, down 50, 60 bps or so from where we were last year. Obviously, the move to 23%, the 1% or so is a function of the higher brand spend. It's a function of where we think we are right now in terms of foreign currency benefit. And then, lastly, it turns out that our international duties from the new international structure, are coming in and going to be, it looks like right now, higher than we were contemplating. And those obviously are in sales. They come out of cost of sales. So there's no impact at the OI line, but just from the math standpoint, it impacts the ROS that we have. And so, for the foreseeable future, given where we are in terms of what we think are our opportunities really for reinforcing the longer-term sustainable growth, I would say that margins in the 23% to 24% rate is really, will be our run rate. Obviously, as this thing kind of planes out of the water and we're moving forward the way we expect to, then we would expect through price mix, as well as leveraging the cost structure, to have further opportunities.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010

componenttext: Craig, first question, if you could. 50% incremental Home and Security, if you kind of square the comments on materials costs, is it safe to say as you kind of roll through this year that, that base 30% incremental margin is something that you're going to be seeing in the Home and Security business?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do think that's where we're. Again, I mean, obviously, we were ecstatic to be leveraging at 50%. But it's just, and the point I was trying to make here, is that it just doesn't really reflect the underlying state of the business. But we do expect t
componenttext: Yes, I do think that's where we're. Again, I mean, obviously, we were ecstatic to be leveraging at 50%. But it's just, and the point I was trying to make here, is that it just doesn't really reflect the underlying state of the business. But we do expect to leverage in that kind of 30%-ish kind of range.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Are you going to be at a loss at some of that commodity headwind that you're facing, so that the realized incremental that we'll see will be around that 30% number?
componenttext: Are you going to be at a loss at some of that commodity headwind that you're facing, so that the realized incremental that we'll see will be around that 30% number?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's kind of interesting. I think everyone's aware of the fact that, that Delta went out and took some actions. But we're looking at that and we'll evaluate that. We'll see what happens here as the market, hopefully, strengthens over the bal
componenttext: Well, I think it's kind of interesting. I think everyone's aware of the fact that, that Delta went out and took some actions. But we're looking at that and we'll evaluate that. We'll see what happens here as the market, hopefully, strengthens over the balance of the year. And yes, there may be some opportunities to deal with that. But we're being cautious at the moment. And as we've said, with the new kind of normal for consumers, I mean, we're operating on the moment that any price increase needs to be very carefully considered.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And as you're gaining share in some of these categories in Home and Security and introducing new products and kind of filling some of these value gaps or price gaps, I guess, can you talk about the profitability of the businesses? Are you seeing things em
componenttext: And as you're gaining share in some of these categories in Home and Security and introducing new products and kind of filling some of these value gaps or price gaps, I guess, can you talk about the profitability of the businesses? Are you seeing things emerge that are markedly different than, say, previous cycle plus or minus, by business?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, these are profitable opportunities. And we really don't gain share without profitable returns. So we're leveraging in some cases our very competitive supply chain that maybe some competitors don't have. We're leveraging some innovations that others h
componenttext: Yes, these are profitable opportunities. And we really don't gain share without profitable returns. So we're leveraging in some cases our very competitive supply chain that maybe some competitors don't have. We're leveraging some innovations that others haven't maybe invested the way they should have during the downturn. So these are -- this is good business.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And the beauty of where we are with our cost structure, this is win-win. It's a win for our customers and it's win for us. So everybody's happy at this point.
componenttext: And the beauty of where we are with our cost structure, this is win-win. It's a win for our customers and it's win for us. So everybody's happy at this point.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'm wondering is, as you come out of this, are you maybe seeing reasons to be a bit more optimistic on what the structural profitability of Home and Security might be, given some of the successes you're having so far?
componenttext: I guess what I'm wondering is, as you come out of this, are you maybe seeing reasons to be a bit more optimistic on what the structural profitability of Home and Security might be, given some of the successes you're having so far?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've said to you, and as we've said publicly to a lot of people, I mean, we do expect that when we get back to kind of true run rate in the business, that we will be looking at margins that are up and approaching that kind of 15% level. And we q
componenttext: Well, as we've said to you, and as we've said publicly to a lot of people, I mean, we do expect that when we get back to kind of true run rate in the business, that we will be looking at margins that are up and approaching that kind of 15% level. And we quantified that from the revenue standpoint as kind of the high $4 billion-ish range, with housing starts in the 1.3 million, 1.5 million range and repair and remodel, that we'd be running at up, kind of mid-single-digit levels. So, I mean, at 15%, approaching 15%, we think, would be pretty healthy.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: On the free cash flow outflow in the quarter, can you give us any insights on what sort of the big drivers there were?
componenttext: On the free cash flow outflow in the quarter, can you give us any insights on what sort of the big drivers there were?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, the first quarter is always an outflow for us, and just as we kind of build our inventory positions in anticipation of kind of where the full year is going to be. So Golf, obviously, is a big piece of that. And we've got product that maturing inve
componenttext: I mean, the first quarter is always an outflow for us, and just as we kind of build our inventory positions in anticipation of kind of where the full year is going to be. So Golf, obviously, is a big piece of that. And we've got product that maturing inventories that we've been writing down in Spirits. But obviously, I mean, when you look at where we are year-over-year, it was better than last year. So I'd say to you that, it's pretty much normal situation.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In the cabinet business, the share gains were pretty stunning relative to the market and relative to others. Can you just talk a little bit about what you think you're doing to drive that magnitude of share progress and the sustainability of that through
componenttext: In the cabinet business, the share gains were pretty stunning relative to the market and relative to others. Can you just talk a little bit about what you think you're doing to drive that magnitude of share progress and the sustainability of that through the year?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We have been awarded new business in the home centers area really at the higher end of the market. And that is both here in the U.S. and Canada. We've also seen some growth in the dealer side of the channel, so which is again in the higher-price-point are
componenttext: We have been awarded new business in the home centers area really at the higher end of the market. And that is both here in the U.S. and Canada. We've also seen some growth in the dealer side of the channel, so which is again in the higher-price-point areas. So I think that how we are structured to go to market is playing well right now. And this is business, as you know, you have to -- this is business really we won last year that really, because you have to put the displays in, you have to get the designers trained, and then it comes two, three months later. So this is things that we expected and positioned last year, and that they've started to work -- move more quickly than we thought in the first quarter. We're very pleased with that.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I'd add here, and we've talked about this before, but I think it also speaks to the intelligence of how we approach costs take-out. We didn't just simply willy-nilly start cutting costs just to save diluted earnings per share. I mean, we w
componenttext: The other thing I'd add here, and we've talked about this before, but I think it also speaks to the intelligence of how we approach costs take-out. We didn't just simply willy-nilly start cutting costs just to save diluted earnings per share. I mean, we were very careful to maintain the national footprints so that we're servicing all of our customers across our channels; to maintain flexibility so we could deal with the volume; and then, lastly, make sure that we are doing the right things so that we have flexibility for our costs as well as being able to deal with new products. And, I mean, it's all bearing fruit.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly within the incremental margin on the business you talked about, the underlying incremental margin in Home, the 30% once you pull out some of the sort of other things in the numbers, I guess I kind of thought maybe that was conservative guidance w
componenttext: Secondly within the incremental margin on the business you talked about, the underlying incremental margin in Home, the 30% once you pull out some of the sort of other things in the numbers, I guess I kind of thought maybe that was conservative guidance when you gave it to us 90 days ago. Is there anything that would suggest the incremental margin can be any better than that in your march back towards 15%? Or is that just kind of how this business structurally sets up?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think -- no. Clearly, I mean, if indeed the consumer is stronger over the balance of the year, then we will get some incremental leverage on that. But that's hard to call at this point because it's going to be a function of where does it come from a
componenttext: No, I think -- no. Clearly, I mean, if indeed the consumer is stronger over the balance of the year, then we will get some incremental leverage on that. But that's hard to call at this point because it's going to be a function of where does it come from and what's kind of the nature of it. So yes, when you look at the price mix. But no, definitely, I think we're positioned that as we get additional volume, then we should get benefit. And so that could start to move higher from the 30s if things really come back.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Spirits business, Bruce, you talked about the new normal. Is there anything you're seeing of concern or interest, more so on the concerns and related to how price mix is playing out as the consumer starts to feel better? Anything that you're seeing
componenttext: In the Spirits business, Bruce, you talked about the new normal. Is there anything you're seeing of concern or interest, more so on the concerns and related to how price mix is playing out as the consumer starts to feel better? Anything that you're seeing there that makes you think differently about where you're going with new product or with the existing portfolio?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Let's talk about the markets we're in. I don't know if you're specifically talking about the U.S., but let's start there. U.S., I think what we saw from the industry last year, was a bit more aggressive promotion and maybe even some pricing behavior i
componenttext:
No. Let's talk about the markets we're in. I don't know if you're specifically talking about the U.S., but let's start there. U.S., I think what we saw from the industry last year, was a bit more aggressive promotion and maybe even some pricing behavior in the middle of the year. And during the Christmas season, I think as I told you, it was back to normal. And during the first quarter, it's back to normal. So the price mix piece is both looking at control and yield and it looks pretty healthy again. It's not as robust as maybe it was in '07 or '06, but it's on the plus. And the volumes are very strong too. So the market -- although it's only one quarter and we don't want to get way ahead of ourselves -- but the U.S. has responded well. Now there are other markets that are a lot more challenging. You go to Spain or you go to the U.K., much more challenging markets. And that's really economy-driven. But Australia's healthy, India's very healthy. Those are markets that we're obviously strong in. Mexico is coming back too. Canada has remained strong. So I would say the ones we're most concerned about are pretty much in Europe, the U.K. and Spain in particular
.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Michael Rehaut from JPMorgan.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I know this has been asked a couple of different ways, and it just appears that you're really just sticking to kind of a conservative wait-and-see approach in terms of the end markets. But all in, with the growth that you had in the first quarter, mathema
componenttext: I know this has been asked a couple of different ways, and it just appears that you're really just sticking to kind of a conservative wait-and-see approach in terms of the end markets. But all in, with the growth that you had in the first quarter, mathematically, unless I'm really off here, you're basically talking about zero growth for the rest of the year to come into a low single-digit type of world. And just going back to the inventory rebuild. I mean, you said that, that might have been, if you're saying share gains are over half of that growth, then inventory rebuild may be one of the remaining segments of that. But still, if you have starts kicking in a bit further and just a stable consumer, it would seem that for Home and Security, for example, you'd do at least a mid-single-digit. And I would say, similarly to Spirits. So, I mean, is there anything that -- and again, I know you guys target conservatism, but, I mean, are you really expecting that type of a dramatic fallback? Or again, is this just ,you'd say, overly conservative?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: At this point, we're not locking down on $2.50 to $2.80. I mean the reality is, I mean, we've taken up the low end to reflect the first quarter. I mean, without question, as we've already outlined, the first quarter results are great. But it also was an e
componenttext: At this point, we're not locking down on $2.50 to $2.80. I mean the reality is, I mean, we've taken up the low end to reflect the first quarter. I mean, without question, as we've already outlined, the first quarter results are great. But it also was an easy-comp quarter. I mean the world was in a freeze in the first quarter of last year. And the reality is right now, as we've said is, we really want to get ourselves to mid-year; have a better sense of just exactly where do we think the year's headed; get a better sense of where we are with commodities; get a better sense of where we are with end markets. And it's going to be at that point that we will update the guidance. So it isn't that we're sitting here hand wringing at the moment. It's just that we want to be kind of prudent and pragmatic and careful, in terms of whatever we're going to give it terms of what our targets are going to be for the full year. But as we've already outlined, I mean we think we've done the right things to position ourselves out in the marketplace. We know we've done the right things from a cost-structure standpoint. And we'll see where we go.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question is more of, I think, a little bit longer-term conceptual on the Spirits business. Clearly, the focus in terms of the 20 brand-country combinations and some of the growth initiatives, I think, are very interesting and show a lot of prom
componenttext: The second question is more of, I think, a little bit longer-term conceptual on the Spirits business. Clearly, the focus in terms of the 20 brand-country combinations and some of the growth initiatives, I think, are very interesting and show a lot of promise. But I was wondering if you could give some type of quantifiable, some broad-brush numbers in terms of what you think the overall market opportunity is in the Spirit categories that you compete? Maybe just some broad numbers, some broad math in terms of what's the overall opportunity in terms of total market, where you think you're competing more aggressively that you stand to gain some share over the next five or ten years?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just sort of put a top summary on it, and I'll let Craig handle this with more finer details. What we've done -- and I think we've explained this to you and a lot of people over the last couple of years -- but what we've tried to do is really focus
componenttext: Let me just sort of put a top summary on it, and I'll let Craig handle this with more finer details. What we've done -- and I think we've explained this to you and a lot of people over the last couple of years -- but what we've tried to do is really focus on what you said the BMC, the brand-market combinations, that have the biggest and best returns. And that may be because of the growth side in a particular market or just how the brand is positioned. So instead of trying to paint everything with one brush, and we have 680 brand-market combinations, we're focusing on the best returns or the best emerging returns. So where we're putting our money is against our best bets. And we're putting significant money behind that. And with that, we're starting to see traction. And that's what we were hoping for. Now, it's been a combinations of a series of strategic moves, including getting a control of our Route to market; getting the brands positioned right from a price-value equation; getting them positioned right to have the right target audience to talk to for these particular brands; and then getting the messages out to them in the right fashion. So this is something, as you know, we've been working on for several years. And we started to see some traction during the Christmas holiday season, and it continued into the first quarter. And , you compound that with some innovation to bring some spark to it, and it really started to work well. Now we have a long way to go. This first quarter is not a big quarter in the Spirits business. And we have very fine-tuned focus. And we hope that this continual investment will purport building these brands and building the equity in these brands. And that will translate eventually into better pricing and to solid growth. And that's the model we're going after. And when you have a business that has a 23% return on sales and you're going after the better part of those returns, it should play well.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And so, Mike, let me engage, just to help you here kind of the modeling here longer term. We've always said that in the Spirits market that the broader model would be that you've got revenues kind of growing low to mid-single digits. You say ballpark, you
componenttext: And so, Mike, let me engage, just to help you here kind of the modeling here longer term. We've always said that in the Spirits market that the broader model would be that you've got revenues kind of growing low to mid-single digits. You say ballpark, you're talking about volumes that are kind of one to two, and then price mix, that could be kind of one of two. That gives you your top line. And then an expectation that you get down to the OI line and you're leveraging that. So that's your kind of mid- to strong mid-single digit OI. And then to, as Bruce just outlined, taking something down to where you got kind of margins, and the margins that we've just set for us kind of for the foreseeable future, kind of 23% to 24%. I mean, that's a pretty terrific model. And it's a business where its also got great cash flow. So that's how we're thinking about it. And our view right now is, more than happy to make some investments behind what we think are really our opportunities to really drive growth. And so for now, to put some money behind that with the expectation that those sales are going to leverage at a 23%, 24% to brand contribution margin level better than that, we clearly think is the right thing to be doing with this business.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And this is brands and markets that we have some momentum in. It's not like we're trying to turn around something. These are things that will have momentum. We're trying to just capitalize on that momentum.
componenttext: And this is brands and markets that we have some momentum in. It's not like we're trying to turn around something. These are things that will have momentum. We're trying to just capitalize on that momentum.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'm just trying to get at is, again, on a much more broad basis, just the overall market size or market opportunity in the Spirits that you compete in, in the countries that you compete in, right now the business is about a $2.5 billion busin
componenttext: I guess what I'm just trying to get at is, again, on a much more broad basis, just the overall market size or market opportunity in the Spirits that you compete in, in the countries that you compete in, right now the business is about a $2.5 billion business. And I'm just trying to get a sense for the overall opportunity. And specifically, just by starting off with just on a broad basis, what is the overall dollar number for the markets you compete in? And how you think about it longer term?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, but as we said, I mean just trying to -- you really have to go market by market. But just kind of broadly speaking, I mean the expectation here is you're looking at global markets that on average, can be kind of up in the kind of maybe 2% to 3%-ish
componenttext: Okay, but as we said, I mean just trying to -- you really have to go market by market. But just kind of broadly speaking, I mean the expectation here is you're looking at global markets that on average, can be kind of up in the kind of maybe 2% to 3%-ish range in a normalized environment. We came into this year a bit more cautious, but are now saying we think they could be kind of up about to 1% or so. We can take this offline with you if you want, but I think that's about as much as we can offer up at this point.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, maybe we'll talk about it later. I'm just trying to get a more of a size than type of a question.
componenttext: Okay, maybe we'll talk about it later. I'm just trying to get a more of a size than type of a question.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, but I mean it's such a -- globally, it's so hugely fragmented, that it just gets challenging to try to just put a kind call it a homogeneous number that peanut-butters across all the markets.
componenttext: Yes, but I mean it's such a -- globally, it's so hugely fragmented, that it just gets challenging to try to just put a kind call it a homogeneous number that peanut-butters across all the markets.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Lindsay Drucker Mann from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to press a little bit on the Spirits performance in the quarter because it was really surprising to see the profit declines despite underlying X-currency and other excise tax issue growth of 7%. But then I think Craig, you mentioned
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to press a little bit on the Spirits performance in the quarter because it was really surprising to see the profit declines despite underlying X-currency and other excise tax issue growth of 7%. But then I think Craig, you mentioned that even underlying that, in inventories it was up three. I mean, I can appreciate the $10 million that you highlighted incremental Route-to-market investments, and then the fact that you've been spending higher on advertising. But that's something that's been going on for the past couple of quarters. So I mean, is there anything else that you can add to kind of illuminate what caused degree of margin pressure that we saw in the period? And how we should think about whether this elevated level of -- what the outlook is, what kind of balance of year, how the timing will play out in terms of market behavior?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm happy to deal with that. First of all, I mean, looking at margins in the first quarter of last year of 27%. I mean, that obviously was aberrational, and in part was a function of just the fact that we had held back brand spend. But just to give y
componenttext: Yes, I'm happy to deal with that. First of all, I mean, looking at margins in the first quarter of last year of 27%. I mean, that obviously was aberrational, and in part was a function of just the fact that we had held back brand spend. But just to give you a sense just year-over-year, if you're looking at 20.7% this year against 27%, so we got basically six points of spread, which on the face of it, you'd say, "My God, what's going on?" But when you start to work your way down, FX accounts for probably about 1.5% or so of that. Route-to-market costs, along with the -- now we've got the international duties that are flowing through sales but don't come down to the OI line, the combination of those two is three points. The brand spend, which for competitive reasons we don't break out specifically nups [ph], that's a big part of it. And then obviously in the quarter, we had some degree of kind of price mix decline. I mean, as you're well aware, last year was a big year for us in terms of what we were able to do with price mix. In fact, I think we were ahead of a lot of the competition. As we kind of came into the tail end of the year, as Bruce outlined, I mean, we had competitors that were taking more aggressive actions. And so in select markets on select products, we've sharpened our pricing to be sure that we're where we need to be. So that's something that also was a factor here in the first quarter. But you know, it's small. And as we're outlining, as we look for the full year, our expectation is that the combination of price and mix -- and I would say to you that for now, price will be somewhat negative, but that mix will be positive. And the net of that will be positive for us. So we're not losing a lot of sleep over the first quarter at this point. It largely is tracking where we expect it to be. And as we look to the full year, we are targeting that with the things we've just outlined, that we will be in that 23-ish % range versus the 24% that we outlined in January.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So when I look at your Spirits sales do I net out excise taxes? So when I look at your margin, it would be operating income over sales less whatever you talked about as excise taxes? Are the international duties that you mentioned, are those something tha
componenttext: So when I look at your Spirits sales do I net out excise taxes? So when I look at your margin, it would be operating income over sales less whatever you talked about as excise taxes? Are the international duties that you mentioned, are those something that's above and beyond what would come out when I net out excise taxes? Or would that actually be reflected in there?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's reflected. When we talked to you about comparable numbers, it's reflected there. But heretofore, we didn't have that when we were selling to old Maxxium, I mean, we were selling to them net of distribution and there were no excise taxes in it. So
componenttext: No, it's reflected. When we talked to you about comparable numbers, it's reflected there. But heretofore, we didn't have that when we were selling to old Maxxium, I mean, we were selling to them net of distribution and there were no excise taxes in it. So now that we've taken over those markets and we're reflecting 100% of those sales in the top line, it has an impact in terms of how you look at our margins, our ROS margins versus where we were in the past.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just back on the inventory issue for Home Products business, if it's about half of your -- if half of your growth was share gain and the other half, call it inventories, that's maybe 6% or so, mid-single digits anyway. It seems like a pretty big amount, e
componenttext: Just back on the inventory issue for Home Products business, if it's about half of your -- if half of your growth was share gain and the other half, call it inventories, that's maybe 6% or so, mid-single digits anyway. It seems like a pretty big amount, especially in light of the fact that it's on products that are maybe 1/3 of your total sales. So I guess I was just wondering, is that inventory, is that the right way to think about it? And is that inventory loading something that will potentially come out of numbers reversed in Q2 through Q4? Or is that sort of permanent in the base?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that remains to be seen in terms of what happens with the market. I mean...
componenttext: Well, I think that remains to be seen in terms of what happens with the market. I mean...

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, 6% wasn't -- when we do the inventory, it's a much lower percentage. So that's not the right assumption there.
componenttext: Well, first off, 6% wasn't -- when we do the inventory, it's a much lower percentage. So that's not the right assumption there.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So can you give us a better sense of quantifying the amount then?
componenttext: So can you give us a better sense of quantifying the amount then?

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let's just kind of come back on this for a moment because our reported sales are up 15%. As we outlined, our comparable sales are up around 12%. And of that 12, more than half of that was share gain. I mean, you kind of call in terms of just exactly
componenttext: Well, let's just kind of come back on this for a moment because our reported sales are up 15%. As we outlined, our comparable sales are up around 12%. And of that 12, more than half of that was share gain. I mean, you kind of call in terms of just exactly where things were with the market. And tight numbers on inventory build is hard to do. But I'd leave it at this point as saying that use your numbers, if you want to say that more than half of the 12 is share gain. And that would come back and say that we're looking at a market, including the distributor inventory builds that would've been up kind of the low to mid-single digits. So I mean, that just frames that. I can't offer you any more than that at this point. I mean, we don't have tight data.

headline: Fortune Brands Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We had market growth as well in there.
componenttext: We had market growth as well in there.

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.
